node.text:
In 2019, eight year old Otto Erlandsen set a goal to hike every summit in Acadia National Park. This past fall, Otto completed his goal, successfully summiting each of the 26 peaks in the park. To congratulate him, park staff passed our hats to him and shared our favorite mountains around the park. Please enjoy this light hearted video in celebration and join us in congratulating Otto by sharing your favorite mountain in the park too! 

View the video at the park website (hyperlinked) for closed captioning and audio description. 

https://www.nps.gov/acad/learn/photosmultimedia/otto-s-hat-pass.htm

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 05, 2021. May be an image of crustacean and nature.

node.text:
Virtual Program: Tide Pool Tales
Saturday, August 7th 
4pm

Tidepooling is a popular activity in Acadia National Park.  Each tide pool is a miniature window to the ocean where many amazing plants and animals can be found. Join us as we learn how to safely explore Acadia’s intertidal habitat and the diversity found within. 

TO REGISTER: Email acaddistancelearning@schoodicinstitute.org 
Please include the name of the program and the date in the subject line (Tide Pool Tales). Register at least 2 hours before the start of the program to receive a link and a confirmation email. 

#AcadiaEducates #FindYourVirtualPark
NPS Photo/ Crystal Lewis

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 04, 2021. May be a closeup of nature.

node.text: Kelly Zehnder, of Roselle, IL, shares a photo of a Calico pennant dragonfly (Celithemis elisa) near Otter Cove on June 16. (Photo courtesy Kelly Zehnder @wildlifebykelly. Used with permission.) More at http://go.nps.gov/YourAcadiaNPS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 04, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
Ranger Noel ventured from Acadia's Islesford Historical Museum on Little Cranberry Island to help out our neighbors at Islesford Boatworks. This community-based non-profit organization teaches boatbuilding skills to children, teens and adults. Islesford Boatworks leases the park's historic Blue Duck Ships building as their home base for preserving local maritime legacy and tradition. 
In island communities, many hands make light work; together they lifted and launched a handcrafted St. Ayles skiff into the water.

Photo credit: Allison Yanover, Steve Richard, Noel Bond/NPS
Photo 1: A large yellow wooden canoe lays on a grassy lawn in front of a brick building.
Photo 2: Four people, including one park ranger, carry a large yellow wooden canoe from a lawn into a street.
Photo 3: Four people, including one park ranger, push a large wooden canoe into water from a concrete boat launch while one person stands in the canoe with an oar.

location.name: Islesford Historical Museum and Blue Duck Ships Store

node.text:
As the Loon Turns – Chapter 2
Friday, July 30 

I arrived at Echo Lake at 8:50 am to see one adult loon, I believe to be last year’s female due to yellow and white bands on her leg, swimming near the floating loon hotel (FLH) or artificial nesting platform (ANP), (I will discuss the FLH/ANP later), and another adult loon on the nest. At 8:55 am the loons switched places. The loon getting on the nest turned the egg and settled, while the other loon swam a few hundred feet away and began preening. All was peaceful and serene for about an hour, when I noticed a third loon swimming near the preening loon. The loon on the nest hopped off the nest and began swimming rapidly towards the third loon. The third loon immediately began its takeoff towards the north, running on the water and rowing its wings. It was soon lost in the mist. The resident pair of loons swam together for a few minutes, and then last year’s female returned to the nest, turned the egg and settled. Everything remained peaceful while I was there. We should be seeing a loon chick in about 2 weeks all things being equal.

A sad note – the Somes Pond chick was attacked and injured by a juvenile bald eagle. It was rescued and taken to be evaluated. Unfortunately, its wounds were deemed too severe and it was put to rest.

Artificial Nesting Platform/Floating Loon Hotel (ANP/FLH) What are they?
- An ANP/FLH are man-made platforms made from cedar logs, PVC pipe and/or other materials. They often have turkey mesh wire used as a shade structure. A generous supply of nesting materials i.e. reeds, grasses, sedge, mud is included to help the loons nest.

Why are ANP/FLH important? The Artificial Nesting Platform, is an important management tool in certain situations:
- Where loons nested in the past, but nests failed due to nest predation i.e. eagles, mink, raccoons
- Where natural or man-made water level fluctuations caused nests to fail - rising water levels have washed eggs out of a nest, or water levels falling that have left a nest too high for the loons to gain access.
- Where nesting habitat was eliminated by shoreline development, i.e. boat docks, campgrounds, cabins, and human disturbance.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 01, 2021. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text: Andrew G. Petlock, of Northborough, MA, shares a portrait of a Common merganser and her chicks at Jordan Pond on May 28. "I was pleasantly surprised by how cooperative the mother was, as mergansers are typically extremely shy birds." (Photo courtesy of Andrew G. Petlock @petlock_photography. Used with permission.) More at http://go.nps.gov/YourAcadiaNPS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on July 31, 2021.

node.text:
Virtual Program: Tide Pool Tales
Saturday, August 7th 
4:00pm

Tidepooling is a popular activity in Acadia National Park.  Each tide pool is a miniature window to the ocean where many amazing plants and animals can be found. Join us as we learn how to safely explore Acadia’s intertidal habitat and the diversity found within. 

TO REGISTER: Email acaddistancelearning@schoodicinstitute.org 
Please include the name of the program in the subject line (Tide Pool Tales). Register at least 2 hours before the start of the program to receive a link and a confirmation email.

For more information about upcoming programs, visit our calendar at https://www.nps.gov/acad/planyourvisit/calendar.htm

#AcadiaEducates #NPSYouth @npsyouth 
NPS Photo/Crystal Lewis

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park in Echo Lake Beach, Mount Desert Island, Maine. May be an image of nature and text that says 'AMERICA THE BEAUTIFUL The Nationa Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass E ACCESS'.

node.text:
July is #DisabilityPrideMonth, a time to celebrate the unique experiences of Acadia’s visitors with disabilities. This week, we also recognize the 31st anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). The ADA helps provide services such as wheelchair accessible buses and braille park guides, as well as expanding employment opportunities for rangers with disabilities. Share your experience visiting Acadia in the comments, whether it’s a favorite travel tip or ways we can improve park accessibility.
 
Planning a trip to Acadia? The Access Pass is a free, lifetime pass to all federal public lands available to visitors with disabilities. Visit nps.gov/acad/planyourvisit/accessibility.htm for accessibility recommendations--like Echo Lake beach!
 

Image description: Access Pass card held in front of a sandy lake beach.
Image Credit: Emma Lanning/NPS

location.name: Echo Lake Beach, Mount Desert Island, Maine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 4 people, people standing, outdoors and tree.

node.text:
Très bien! Acadia’s rich French history and place names were the subject of a special talk given by Park Ranger Kim Eadie (in French!) to a group of French teachers from the Maine Chapter of the American Association of Teachers of French (AATF) at Sieur de Monts last week.
Photo 1: A ranger smiles as she shows a park map to a group surrounding her under a shady tree.
Photo 2: A circle of people watch a ranger talk as she gestures to a paper map.
Photo Credit: NPS

location.name: Sieur De Monts Springs Nature Center

node.text: Christopher Horton, a member of the park's trail crew, shares additional images of raging storm runoff along Kurt Diederich's Climb following a dramatic weather event across the park June 9. Repairs continue to part of the Maple Spring Trail and a section of carriage road between Intersections 10 and 12. Track closure updates at go.nps.gov/AcadiaAlerts

node.text: Bryan Walwyn shares a photo he posted in October 2020 from the Beehive Trail. "Fall hits different in Maine." (Photo courtesy Bryan Balwyn @bwal8705. Used with permission.) More at http://go.nps.gov/YourAcadiaNPS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on July 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, footwear, outdoors and tree.

node.text: Sarah McCartt-Jackson, a current writer-in-residence at Acadia National Park, connects with a visitor from Long Island, NY during an informal outreach activity Monday outside Sieur de Monts Nature Center. McCartt-Jackson is a poet, oral historian, and folklorist from Louisville, KY ... sarahmccarttjackson.com ... Apply now through Sept 30 for residency opportunities at Acadia in 2022. More at go.nps.gov/AcadiaArt

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park in Acadia National Park. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Do you know why common loons have red eyes?  Ranger Emily loves helping families discover more of Acadia National Parks' natural beauty at Junior Ranger Stations!  Come join us, explore, and become part of the next generation of public lands stewards.
Learn how you can become a Junior Ranger at Family & Kids Activities - Acadia National Park (U.S. National Park Service) (nps.gov)
